title: Support connection pool reaping for redis
body:
As of Sidekiq 7.0, [connection pools are managed internally in Sidekiq](https://github.com/sidekiq/sidekiq/wiki/Using-Redis#using-an-initializer). However, there are edge cases where this can present a problem.

Recently, we started routing Sidekiq redis traffic through an Envoy TCP proxy. By default, Envoy has a 1-hour idle timeout for its TCP proxy connections. No other layer of our infrastructure implements this timeout mechanism, and so this is net-new.

When we began routing this traffic through Envoy, we started seeing high numbers of SSL and broken pipe errors, depending on which redis clients we were using - for older implementations (e.g. 4.5.x), we see `SSL_read: unexpected eof` errors; for newer implementations (e.g. 5.4.x), we see `broken pipe`. In either case, these appear to be caused by the idle connection timeouts in Envoy.

Also, in either case, these cause job failures.

Ultimately, the problem appears to be caused by Envoy closing a connection, followed by Sidekiq - via redis-client - attempting to access the now-closed socket. Envoy recommends not disabling idle timeouts, as this can lead to leaky connections and cause performance degradation.

`connection_pool` allows creation of a reaper thread. While I believe it is technically possible to manage Sidekiq's pool out of band, this generally seems like a bad idea for a pool which is intended to be internal to Sidekiq.

Would adding reaper support be feasible? Or do you recommend simply running an out-of-band reaper thread within application code? And if the latter, could documentation be updated to make this explicit?
